graph

Class DynamicGraph<T extends ValueNode,S extends Edge<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • graph.DynamicGraph<T,S>
  • Type Parameters:
    T -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Graph<T,S>

    public class DynamicGraph<T extends ValueNode,S extends Edge<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Graph<T,S>
    This graph is dynamic in the sense that it builds up its node set in runtime, using a given neighborProvider. It does not actually keep a set of nodes already searched, as this could create a big memory waste.
    Author:
    Stijn
    See Also:
    NeighborProvider, LinkedGraph, ExplicitGraph

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DynamicGraph(NeighborProvider<T,S> provider)
      Use this constructor if you want nodes be made dynamically.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean containsNode(T node)
      Returns true if the graph contains given node.
      double getCostBetween(T node0, T node1)
      Returns the cost between the given nodes, if the graph is directed, it returns the cost from node0 to node1.
      java.util.Set<S> getEdgesFrom(T node)
      Returns a set of one way edges to all the neighbors of the given node, it encapsulates both the neighbor and the cost, so no need for two separate methods.
      java.util.Set<T> getNeighborsOf(T node)
      Returns the neighbors to the given node.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

      • getCostBetween

        public double getCostBetween(T node0,
                    T node1)
        Description copied from interface: Graph
        Returns the cost between the given nodes, if the graph is directed, it returns the cost from node0 to node1. If not reachable, returns Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
        Specified by:
        getCostBetween in interface Graph<T extends ValueNode,S extends Edge<T>>
